awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Multilayer Co-extrusion Processing of Thermally Conductive Polymer Nanocomposites
awd_abstract_narration:
Polymer composites are materials systems with two or more components where the resulting properties can be tailored by the choice and placement of the individual materials during processing.  Polymers are normally poor thermal conductors, but when combined with thermally conductive nanofillers, can result in a polymer composite with desirable conductivity for applications such as microelectronic packaging, substrates for LED-lighting, and solar panel seals. Multilayer co-extrusion, a novel manufacturing technology, provides a promising route to fabricate polymer composites of desirable architecture and properties. Through rational materials design, advanced manufacturing, and structure-property measurements, this award identifies key factors that affect heat conduction in polymer composites and establishes a polymer processing approach to manufacture thermally conductive nanocomposites for applications with significant socio-economic impact. This highly interdisciplinary research provides rich education and training opportunities for students of diverse backgrounds from high-school to graduate level. 

Multilayer co-extrusion processing, when combined with proper design of the precursor materials, could produce nanocomposites with desired microstructure - forming a nanofiller percolation network to enable efficient heat conduction. However, several scientific questions remain to be answered, such as optimal nanofiller characteristics, the most effective way to form percolation networks at a low filler loading, and the desired thermal contact morphology. This project aims to fill the knowledge gap through systematic studies covering the entire research loop of designing materials based on fundamental understanding of multiscale thermal transport mechanisms, tuning the manufacturing processes to achieve desired microstructures, and characterizing the thermal conductivity of the resulting composites to obtain new design insights. The collaborative study tests the central hypothesis that well-controlled multilayer co-extrusion processing can produce thermally conductive polymer composites with true percolation networks formed by direct contacts between anisotropic nanofillers and an optimal network morphology with low contact thermal resistance. This research project is a collaboration between a team that explores co-extrusion of multilayer nanocomposites to generate the desired microstructures and a team that characterizes thermal transport properties to provide insights into materials design and performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project pursues fundamental understanding of thermal transport through various nanostructures and their contacts, which plays critical roles in the design and manufacturing of thermally conductive polymer composites. The outcomes of this project include (1) the finding of bi-directional modulation of the contact thermal resistance between boron nitride nanotubes (BNNTs) by a polymer interlayer between two BNNTs, (2) the quantitative demonstration of the low contact thermal resistance between silver nanowires and the low interfacial thermal resistance between silver nanowires and polymer matrix, and (3) the unexpected discovery of the nominally negative contact thermal resistance between BNNTs when one end of the BNNT is coated with a layer of Au and is in contact with a bare tube segment. This triggered a systematic study of how Au-coating at one end of a polar nanostructure can efficiently launch phonon polaritons, hybrid quasi-particles resulting from coupling between infrared photons and optically active phonons; and how these phonon polaritons can significantly alter the thermal properties of the uncoated segment of the polar nanostructure. The result represents the first conclusive experimental evidence of phonon polariton-mediated heat conduction along polar nanostructures and the discovery has been reported in Nature, one of the most prestigious scientific journal. In addition, this project has partially supported the education of three Ph.D. students who have got trained to conduct interdisciplinary research. Two of these three graduate students have successfully completed their Ph.D. programs and joined STEM work force.

First, direct measurements of the contact thermal resistance between individual nanostructures indicate that the contact between silver nanowires poses a much lower resistance than that between BNNTs. This result provides important insights into a long-standing puzzle in the thermal properties of nanocomposites. A general observation from numerous studies suggests that while carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and BNNTs can have much higher thermal conductivities than metal particles and nanowires, the CNT- and BNNT-based nanocomposites usually have a lower thermal conductivity than metal particle/wire-based nanocomposites. Even though different hypotheses have been proposed to explain this observed trend, solid experimental data to validate and support the argument have been lacking. Our results provide direct experimental evidence suggesting that the contact thermal resistance between CNTs and BNNTs could be an important factor for the low performance of these high thermal conductivity nanotubes as nanofillers for thermally conductive nanocomposites.

In addition, in view of the different possible contact morphologies, we measured the contact thermal resistance between BNNTs with and without a thin (~13 nm thick) polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) interlayer between two tube segments. Interestingly, results show that the low thermal conductivity PVP interlayer can modulate the contact thermal resistance bi-directionally. For larger diameter (>80 nm) BNNTs, the PVP interlayer leads to a higher contact thermal resistance than that without the PVP interlayer. In contrast, for thinner tubes (<74 nm diameter), the PVP interlayer actually renders a lower contact thermal resistance than that between the corresponding bare tubes. Detailed analysis indicates that this bi-directional modulation is due to that while the PVP interlayer adds a thermal resistance from diffusive transport of energy carriers through the PVP, it eliminates a thermal resistance related to back reflection of ballistically transport energy carriers. This novel finding provides new insights for better design of the thermal pathways in BNNT-polymer nanocomposites.

Inspired by the reduced contact thermal resistance between BNNTs with low thermal conductivity PVP as the interlayer, we further measured the contact thermal resistance between BNNTs with a high thermal conductivity Au interlayer through coating one end of the BNNT segment with a thin layer of Au (~10 nm thick). Results show that the Au interlayer can indeed remarkably reduce the contact thermal resistance. However, the derived contact thermal resistance becomes negative at low temperatures, which is truly unexpected. Careful analysis leads to the hypothesis that the negative contact thermal resistance is due to that the Au-coating efficiently launches phonon polaritons as additional energy carriers to propagate along the uncoated tube segment. To verify this hypothesis, we measured the thermal conductivity of both BNNTs and SiC nanowires, two types of polar nanostructures that can support the transport of phonon polaritons. Thermal measurement results show that for the same BNNTs or SiC nanowires, a short Au coating at the end of the BNNT/SiC nanowire could lead to an enhanced thermal conductivity for the uncoated segment of the tube/wire. This provides the first solid experimental data indicating that phonon polaritons can make significant contributions to heat conduction along polar thin films/nanowires, a theoretical prediction that has not been confirmed for almost twenty years since it was first proposed. This discovery provides a new efficient heat conduction channel that could help dissipate waste heat from microelectronic devices, an issue that is becoming more and more problematic as the key feature sizes in microelectronic devices shrink to the nanometer scale.

 


Last Modified: 05/28/2024
Modified by: Deyu Li
